Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I stared at my phone, torn. Earlier, my acquaintance Sam had messaged, “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this afternoon? I’d really appreciate it.” I knew he didn’t have many friends in town, and I’d always tried to be supportive when someone reached out. But my shift as a telemarketer was about to start, and lately, the calls had been relentless. Prospects kept asking technical questions about our new service—questions my script barely covered. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to never say “I don’t know,” and to keep the calls moving. I could already feel the pressure building in my chest, imagining Sam’s disappointment if I said no, and my boss’s frustration if I got flustered on the phone. Both roles demanded my attention, my time, and my best self. I wanted to help Sam, but I also needed to keep my job. My thumb hovered over the keyboard, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
